awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Impact of the emerging engineering education research and innovation community
awd_abstract_narration:
There is currently little understanding of how to assess and document the impact of discipline-based research on education practice. The goal of this project is to establish such a process and begin to document the impact of the engineering education research and innovation (EER&I) community. It specifically addresses two questions: 1) What is the local and broad impact of selected EER&I programs? 2) What are the best ways to characterize and document the impact of these EER&I programs?  Over the last 20 years significant progress has been made in better understanding how to improve engineering education, much of which has been funded by NSF. However, incorporation of research results into practice has not kept pace with the research enterprise, largely because there is little understanding of how to measure that impact. This proposal aims to address this gap; doing so would lead to significant change in the practice of engineering education. 

The specific goal of this project is to develop and test a process for documenting the impact of engineering education research. This process will be framed around the business canvas model from the NSF I-Corps L program. The work will proceed through three primary activities: document the emerging network of EER&I faculty and identify examples of impact; conduct a summit for EER&I leaders and change experts to develop a process for documenting impact; and pilot the process at the three collaborating institutions. The process will then be tested at additional institutions, including those that do not have engineering education research activities. The results of the project will be summarized in a report and presented at the ASEE Annual Conference. By developing a process for documenting and assessing impact, research results can be more effectively transferred into practices to improve the professional formation of engineers.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this collaborative project between Arizona State University (ASU), Purdue University and Virginia Tech was to explore establishing a process for documenting the impact of the emerging engineering education research and innovation (EER&I) community. The project was responsive to the longstanding challenge of how to effectively and comprehensively document the impact of discipline-based education research (i.e. engineering education research) on the practice of discipline-based engineering education. In addition, over the past two decades, EER-focused PhD programs have been established at several institutions across the US and globally, demonstrating the institutionalization of engineering education research (EER) as a scholarly field. Results of the project inform the role that these emerging PhD programs, combined with other EER-focused efforts broadly, contribute to the impact on the EER&I community, and to engineering education in general.

Outcomes of the project include hosting a summit on the impact of engineering education research & innovation that was attended by researchers from the collaborating universities as well as by 24 EER&I leaders at several other institutions. Collectively, participants identified a range of metrics for documenting EER&I impact and also ways to communicate that impact. Input from the summit also led to identifying and implementing pilot studies for defining and measuring impact, based on metrics discussed at the summit, as well as within the literature.  

 The intellectual merit of the project includes the outcomes of the summit, and the subsequent definition of impact metrics, results from pilot studies, and approaches to dissemination. We have clustered the various metrics into broad categories including leadership, curricular/pedagogical innovations, research, and growing the community. Within these broad categories are subcategories that further define how we might comprehensively document impact. Moreover, results from the project, including the collective voice of the EER&I community, suggest that the full way to document impact is from both a quantitative, as well as qualitative perspective.

Some of the quantitative metrics of impact identified include research expenditures, publications, number of graduates, and awards/recognitions. These are familiar metrics as it relates to research in general but for scholarship within EER additional metrics could also include increased student retention, growth in programs, and curricular innovations implemented, shared and adopted. From a qualitative perspective the project identified the importance of documenting the different pathways and stories of impact to bring visibility to the nuanced ways individuals, programs, institutions, and other groups contribute to the EER&I community. As an example of this nuance, from the study conducted at Arizona State University, we found that institutional structure, opportunities and expectations for EER faculty in teaching engineering courses, and the focus on engineering education as a system, contribute to how EER faculty and PhD students frame their research questions.  

By providing equal focus on qualitative and quantitative measures, and being comprehensive about what counts as impactful, the broader impact of the project provides an approach that can lead to increased clarity in the EER&I community regarding the different types of impacts, what measures are appropriate, and improved practices in realizing, measuring, and disseminating impacts.
